title: 115_s1843
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop CEO Excessive Pay Act" and includes a provision to deny deductions for payments of excessive compensation. The "Stop CEO Excessive Pay Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to disallow deductions for excessive compensation paid to employees, defining excessive compensation as exceeding the median compensation of all employees multiplied by 25 or $1,000,000. The subsection defines compensation to include various forms of remuneration, employer is treated as a single taxpayer, and employee includes full-time, part-time, and seasonal employees. Reporting requirements apply to employers providing any. Reporting requirements for employers providing excessive compensation include filing a report with the Secretary detailing the lowest, highest, and median compensation of employees, the number of employees receiving excessive compensation, and the individual compensation amounts. The amendment prohibits deductions for fines paid to the SEC related to executive compensation. It applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 prohibits deductions for fines paid to the SEC related to executive compensation. It applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment introduces limitations on executive compensation, defining it broadly to include various forms of remuneration. The compensation paid to an issuer's employee in a taxable year cannot exceed $1,000,000 or 25 times the amount. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment imposes restrictions on executive compensation, capping it at $1,000,000 or 25 times the median compensation of all employees. An exception allows payment if approved by at least 50% of shareholders within 18 months before the end of the taxable year. Proxy materials must be provided for shareholder approval. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment requires issuers to disclose compensation details of employees before a shareholder vote. This includes the lowest paid employee's compensation, highest paid employee's compensation, median compensation of all employees, number of employees paid over 25 times the median, and total compensation of those employees. The Commission may impose a civil penalty on issuers for non-compliance. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment requires issuers to disclose employee compensation details before a shareholder vote. A civil penalty may be imposed on an issuer if they pay an employee more than $1,000,000 or 25 times the median compensation of all employees in a taxable year, and if a shareholder vote is not conducted or if less than 50% of shareholders approve the compensation. The penalty for paying an employee more than $1,000,000 or 25 times the median compensation of all employees in a taxable year is outlined in the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment. The Securities and Exchange Commission must issue final rules within 1 year to enforce section 16(h) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
